To clear up another misconception, there has *not* been a trend of schools for the Deaf closing down. In the past 10 years there has only been *one* closure, and that was in the Virginia where one of two schools were closed. Prior to that, ten years ago in North Carolina in 2001, one of three schools for the Deaf was closed. A very tiny school for the Deaf was closed in the Wyoming in 2001 that was only 40 years old, and the Nebraska School for the Deaf was closed in 1998. One need only consult the website of the Laurent Clerc Center at Gallaudet University to see that there currently residential schools for the Deaf in all but 3 or 4 US states.

Also, in regard to the previous comment, it is inappropriate to compare Brown vs. Board of Ed. to the situation of Deaf vs. mainstream schools. Sorry, but there is very little authentic intergration of Deaf students that occurs at mainstream schools. That is "faux integration." One must thinking more deeply to understand that Deaf student *want* to attend schools for the Deaf, and that is so that they may better integrate into society as a whole by becoming educated citizens.

i love books and one of my favorite jobs was working in publishing. And even though I was working in IT, I was feeling very old school about books. We mustn't forget that each is a work of art that has been touched by various hands, minds & creativity to come into birth. The texture of the pages, the chosen fonts and interior design, the particular size and weight of the object...how it looks and feels in your hand, all offered a very tactile relationship beyond just the words. Ebooks, on the other hand, are another option of living; like ipods they offer thousands of options in a small package, a certain physical freedom & economy.

I am in the midst of getting rid of my cds but I will still miss the art of the cover and the long forgotten but at times delicious liner notes that one could sit and digest while listening. Enveloping yourself in the experience.

Books can always be bought again. The beauty of donating is that you are not just churning the economy but offering someone else an opportunity to experience what you did (and at a cheaper price). Kinda like spreading the word and reseeding the fields for others. Save the books that have the most memories tied to them, the ones you may thumb through when those moments hit. Let the rest take their own journeys into other relationships...set them free.

I've had friends with similar issues during their moves. Usually a few of their favorites stay with them, while others are donated. I'm pretty sure I don't know anyone who actually went and threw any of their books out. Throwing out is completely unnecessary. Leave it at a cafe, or office, leave it on the street for a homeless person to find, anything, just don't throw it in the trash.

Beyond that, one practice I find myself doing a lot lately is finding used books on Amazon or Gemm for super cheap, cheaper than what I would find in the Kindle store. Pennies cheap. I purchase and what I get is always fine and decent to read. But that's not what I'm after, I unbind the book and send it through my xerox to make my own digital copy. The unbind/dissembled book is then placed in a binder and added to a collection of other binders and I donate, well give to friends.

As for books you want to absolutely keep for its meaning once you get so many, one thing you can do is box them up, and put them in storage. You pay the fee for storage but eh...you get to keep them.

For decades maps have represented a helpful source when driving on a trip, navigating a walking trail or finding a specific location.  A digital edition map has several advantages over the traditional printed map. Digital maps are equipped with real-time satellite data (global positioning system,GPS or GIS), so we are receiving the most accurate and current information. Most digital map allows us to retrace our steps by pressing a few buttons. If our traditional map is overly used, this task could be quite difficult. Digital maps keep a complete history of our trip. We can archive our directions. The next time we take that route, the directions we followed can easily be retrieved. No need to ask for directions. A digital map identifies our current, exact location if we happen to get lost. By entering the name of our desired location (for example, a specific address or business) in the search field, a digital map provides a list of possible locations. We can select the location that meets our needs. A digital map accurately calculates the distance of a trip. We do not have to estimate the distance (or probable time) when we use a digital map

A case where EUROPE'S PRIVATE system outperforms the U.S. PUBLIC system:

As with any industry, firm and transparent regulations are in the long-term best interest of everyone involved. While the FDA certainly needs to maintain rigorous standards, it must do so in a consistent, transparent manner. In the European system, where devices are regulated by private entities, guidelines are rigorous but also clear and consistent. As a result, studies have shown that innovative, life-saving devices reach patients much quicker in Europe and have no greater incidence of adverse events. As an added benefit, Europe has seen an increase in jobs and innovation as companies avoid the uncertain and bureaucratic regulatory environment in the U.S.
